instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01700: What is 820-01700? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3217: What is CD3217? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP5V_G3S: What is PP5V_G3S? PP5V_G3S is a 5v power rail present when the system is in a G3S standby state.
definitions.PP1V8_SLPS2R: What is PP1V8_SLPS2R? PP1V8_SLPS2R is a 1.8v power rail present when the system is in a SLPS2R state. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H_RTC: What is PP3V3_G3H_RTC? PP3V3_G3H_RTC Is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..
definitions.PP1V8_AWAKE: What is PP1V8_AWAKE? The PP1V8_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is indicative of a power rail that delivers 1.8 volts when the machine is in an "awake" state. This is not a traditional power state defined in the older Intel PCH documentation; it seems to be specific to newer MacBook architectures. The "awake" designation likely refers to a state where the MacBook is on and ready for user interaction, but it is not necessarily at full operational capacity (which would be denoted by an S0 state).
definitions.PP1V1_SLPS2R: What is PP1V1_SLPS2R? The PP1V1_SLPS2R power rail in the MacBook schematic provides a 1.1-volt supply in a specific low-power state indicated by the "_SLPS2R" suffix and is used for powering the T2 chip..
definitions.PP1V2_AWAKE: What is PP1V2_AWAKE? The PP1V2_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides 1.2 volts and is associated with the machine's awake state and is used for powering the T2 chip..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 stuck at 5v 0.249a
threads.message:
Hello everyone !

First post here :p so i have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 with <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP>, water damage near JB500, <CHIP>U9080</CHIP>, <CHIP>U9000</CHIP>, UB300, UB400 and around all this composants.
Change UB300/400 with <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> from aliexpress...
When i plug the charger, 5v 0.249a on all usb-c ports without battery plug, and 20v 0.00a with battery plug.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 12.39v

<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> no present
<SIGNAL>PMU_VDDMAIN_EN</SIGNAL> no present ( normal ? )
<SIGNAL>P3V3G3H_VFB_R</SIGNAL> 0.98V ( normal ? EDIT : Yes, tested on another board )

rails present :

<SIGNAL>CHGR_EN_MVR</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_T</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_AWAKE</SIGNAL>
PP1V8_SLPS2R_PMUVDDGPIO
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_SLPS2R</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP0V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP0V82_SLPS2R</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_AWAKE</SIGNAL>
PPVDDCPUSRAM_AWAKE
<SIGNAL>PP0V9_SLPDDR</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>P1V1_SLPDDR_SOCFET_EN</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_SLPDDR</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_AWAKE</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PPVDDCPU_AWAKE</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PMU_COLD_RESET_L</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PMU_SYS_ALIVE</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PMU_ACTIVE_READY</SIGNAL>

I assume that if i have 20v with battery, all <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> are good ?

Thanks for your help !

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 stuck at 5v 0.249a
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

Check voltage and diode mode to ground on LDO rails from all <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> chips.
Post diode mode to ground at L9020/30/80.

If all AWAKE and SLPS2R voltages are present, you can try to enter DFU mode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 stuck at 5v 0.249a
threads.message:
Thanks for help :)

LDO rails :

PP3V3 0.480/0.500 3.38v on all chips
PP1V5 0.480/0.500 1.59v on all chips

L9020 0.363
30 0.358
80 0.118 ( low i think :/ )

also i found that  <SIGNAL>P3V3MAIN_PGOOD</SIGNAL> not present

I go try dfu mode

EDIT : impossible to go on DFU

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 stuck at 5v 0.249a
threads.message:
"When i plug the charger, 5v 0.249a on all usb-c ports without battery plug"
This is high too much.
Do you note any chip heating abnormal (maybe T2)?
An IR cam can help in this case.

I cannot confirm L9020/30/80 readings, as no similar board available.
If you don't get voltages there, T2 cannot access its partition.

Failing to enter into DFU, should be T2, or SSD problem.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 stuck at 5v 0.249a
threads.message:
Ok i go look for heating tuesday cause my IR cam is at work, meanwhile i go test voltages of SSD.
thanks a lot for your time and see you on tuesday :)

EDIT: no voltages at all on L9020/30/80

threads.message: So sorry, i just have retry DFU mode, and its recognized ( this system is so creepy...) i try revive and tell you

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 stuck at 5v 0.249a
threads.message:
Hello, 

So, after try revive and restore, error 4005, no voltage on any nand.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 stuck at 5v 0.249a
threads.message:
Liquid spill on <CHIP>U9000</CHIP>/80 probably damaged NAND chips.
As you don't have real short on the coil, you can stil resolder that area and rebuild traces, inspect surrounding components.
Should be good to resolder <CHIP>U9000</CHIP>/80.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 stuck at 5v 0.249a
threads.message: I already try this this morning, change <CHIP>U9000</CHIP>/80, clean and resolder all this area, check all resistor in this area too, same problem :/ If I understood correctly, I should normally have voltage on the nand, and from what I saw on the schematics, <CHIP>U9000</CHIP> communicates by SCL/SDA with T2, so I deduce that T2 activates <CHIP>U9000</CHIP> right ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 stuck at 5v 0.249a
threads.message:
The big damage can come through <CHIP>U9080</CHIP>, as this one is powered from <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.
Both chips require <SIGNAL>SSD1_VR_P2V5_EN</SIGNAL> signal, apart of power rails.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 stuck at 5v 0.249a
threads.message: <SIGNAL>SSD1_VR_P2V5_EN</SIGNAL> present when i remove <CHIP>U9000</CHIP>, but when resoldering it, 0.00V ?

threads.message:
Hopeless project, NAND chips have specific information.
You can try, if have time to spend on it.
